thread.title: Jong-nam's next-of-kin expected in Malaysia within days
thread.title_full: Jong-nam's next-of-kin expected in Malaysia within days - Nation | The Star Online

author: thestar.com.my
title: Jong-nam's next-of-kin expected in Malaysia within days
text:
MUAR: A family member of murdered North Korean national Kim Jong-nam is expected to arrive in Malaysia within the next few days.
Deputy Inspector-General of Police Tan Sri Noor Rashid Ibrahim said the victim's relative would be in the country in one or two days to identify and claim the body.
"This will definitely help solve several issues as so far none of the deceased's family members have come forward despite several media reports which claimed they have.
"Either his children or a close relative will come and we will wait for their arrival," he said when met during the official opening of the Bukit Kepong emergency gallery here on Thursday.
There was a media frenzy at the KL International Airport 2 arrival hall on Monday when word got out that Kim Han-sol, Jong-nam's son, would arrive from Macau. This proved to be false.
Noor Rashid added that police were not under pressure to solve the case immediately despite the fact that Jong-nam's death has received worldwide attention.
"We are not stressed at all but what is important is that the police are able to do our job well and in line with international law procedures," he said.
Jong-nam, 45, the estranged half-brother of North Korea supreme leader Kim Jong-un, was assassinated on Feb 13 at the KLIA2 by two women who poisoned him.
Four people have so far been arrested in relation to the case. 
They are Vietnamese Doan Thi Huong, 28; Indonesian Siti Aisyah, 25; North Korean Ri Jong-chol, 47, and Siti Aisyah's boyfriend, Malaysian Muhammad Farid Jalaluddin.  
The remand for Doan and Siti Aisyah was extended for a further seven days while the boyfriend is to be released on police bail.
Four North Koreans who were involved in the murder have returned to Pyongyang. Malaysian police have requested the North Korean government to hand them over.
